stem: The nurse in the labor and delivery unit is reviewing the electronic fetal monitor (EFM) and the client's EHR. Based on the documented findings, match the EFM strip description to the most likely physiological cause.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
13:00: G2P1 client at 39 weeks gestation, admitted in active labor. Cervix is 6cm dilated, 90% effaced, -1 station. Internal fetal scalp electrode placed for better tracing. 
13:15: Client received an epidural bolus for pain management. 
13:30: Nurse notes a decrease in fetal heart rate (FHR) that begins after the peak of the contraction and returns to baseline long after the contraction has ended. 
13:45: Client's blood pressure dropped to 92/54 following the epidural. 
14:00: Another FHR pattern noted as 'abrupt' drops that look like a 'W' or 'V' shape, occurring regardless of contraction timing.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
Cervix: 7cm / 100% / 0 station. 
Membranes: Ruptured (SROM) at 12:45, fluid is clear with no odor. 
Fetal Position: ROA (Right Occiput Anterior). 
Maternal Status: Reports feeling lightheaded and nauseated since the epidural dose.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
1. Position client in lateral recumbent position (Left side). 
2. Administer 500mL IV fluid bolus (Lactated Ringer's). 
3. Apply oxygen 10L via non-rebreather mask if FHR remains non-reassuring. 
4. Notify provider of Category II/III patterns.

rows.text: FHR decrease that mimics the contraction (mirrors)
FHR decrease that begins after the peak of contraction and returns late
Abrupt, sharp FHR drops (V, U, or W shape) unrelated to contractions

rationale.correct: Early decelerations (r1) mirror the contraction and are caused by fetal head compression during labor (benign). Late decelerations (r2) start after the contraction peak and indicate uteroplacental insufficiency, often caused by maternal hypotension (seen here at 92/54). Variable decelerations (r3) are sharp/abrupt and indicate umbilical cord compression. A sinusoidal pattern (r4) is rare and serious, indicating fetal anemia or severe hypoxia.
clinicalPearls: VEAL CHOP is the gold standard mnemonic for FHR patterns.
Late decelerations + Maternal Hypotension after an epidural require a side-lying position and a fluid bolus to restore placental perfusion.
Variables are 'V' shaped and require a position change to relieve pressure on the cord.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking all decelerations are bad and require stopping the Pitocin.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Identify the 'Mirror' vs 'Late' onset. Early decelerations (mirrors) are normal and do not require intervention.

mnemonic.title: VEAL CHOP
mnemonic.expansion: V-Variable = C-Cord. E-Early = H-Head. A-Accelerations = O-Oxygenated (Good). L-Late = P-Placenta.
